content.description: Start by climbing the bolted line Lower Rosie and clip the final bolt on that route instead of moving right to the anchors. From here move up and left following the overhanging crack. Climb the finger and hand crack up the overhanging headwall onto the slab. Move right to chain anchors of Ring Around the Rosie
content.protection: QD's for the bottom and a rack of small & medium cams for the upper crack
content.location: Same as for Lower Rosie

content.description: Start up We Were Jumpers Once and Young (an excellent 1 pitch, 35meter 12c) and, at the 11th bolt, head left and up a left-leaning tips seam to the anchors of Endurance
content.protection: 11 bolts and fixed pins, finish at the Endurance anchors.  Bring a couple of RP's and a 1" camp

climbs.name: We Were Jumpers Once and Young

content.description:
Will most likely be done in two pitches.

 The first pitch is 5.12 power through a bulge to enduro face above leads to first set of anchors. 65 feet.

 Second pitch (5.11c) follows up sustained face climbing through a very aesthetic headwall finish through a thin seam. Bring a small selection of wires and single cams from finger to tight hands to finish out. The "fixed" Leeper-Z fell out on an attempt in 2015 but it should still take gear just fine. 110' foot pitch if done as a single push from the ground.
content.protection:
First pitch has 6 bolts and one fixed draw. 

  14 bolts if done in one long pitch (use a 70m rope) 

  wires and set of cams from fingers to tight hands
content.location: First route from left on the Renegade overhangs wall, start in a corner/seam through blocky terrain to a right-facing horn.  Get your self together now cause here's the business.

content.description: Fun 5.12 to a good rest at the 5th bolt, horrible slopers to a desperate finish, enjoy!  Easier if conditions are cold and you hang a long draw on the bolt above the rest.  A stick clip will be appreciated.
content.location: The route is the first route right of "Live to Pull".

content.description: I felt this climb, just left of Fire on the Mountain, was the best fully bolted climb at the Shack under 5.12.  Good rock, and a sustained crux on a tricky arête made it rewarding.  The slab face passing the last couple of bolts has some lichen but it's no big deal.
content.protection: Bolts to fixed bolted anchors. (10 bolts? I didn't count.)
content.location: Bolted line 10' left of Fire on the Mountain.

climbs.name: Tempest
climbs.fa: FA -  A. Miller,  FFA -  Mike Tritt

content.description: Start on the right side of the crag in the Renaissance sector, on the lower-Tempest 5.8 pitch. Continue after the first anchors into the steep bulge where you will be required to make sustained technical and balancey movement through flawless rock for 6 more bolts.
content.location: Far right end of Shack, just around corner right from stunning arete of Ring Around the Rosie.

climbs.name: Standing on the Edge of Extinction

content.description:
Thin start on near vertical slab.   

  Pull through pumpy bulge to face climbing above. 

  Bring at least one long draw.
content.location: Right most route on Renegade Wall

content.description: Start on a blunt arete with tricky moves to the second bolt.  Head up to a steep headwall for 3 more bolts.
content.location: Between Extinction and Renegade

climbs.name: Ring Around The Rosie
climbs.fa: Ed Strang- bolted by Mike Tupper

content.description: The route climbs the overhanging arête above the Renaissance Wall. Start by climbing Lower Rosie or lower Tempest to the anchors. Continue past these with difficulty on small holds and a powerful heel hook to a good clipping hold. If you make it past this there's an exciting 5.12 slab to get past before you can clip the chains
content.location: Right side of Renaissance Wall

content.description: This is the layback flake to the right of City Girl on the Renaissance Wall. Layback the lower part of the flake then follow bolts to the right past some crumbly rock. Continue up and right to the anchors of Asian Whore.   A nice looking line that unfortunately gets a bit dirty & crumbly in the middle. Hopefully with time it will clean up
content.protection: 5 or 6 bolts to lowering chains/biners   Stick-clip can be helpful since the section to the 1st bolt is a bit funky
content.location: 15 feet right of City Girl at the crack/layback flake

content.description: Start up Renaissance past 5 bolts, bring cams .5 to 2" for the next 25 feet.  After the crux of "Rosie" lean right and clip the bolt step right 15 feet and finish on pocket full of posies.

Bouldery start off ground, then face crux to roof. Steep, pumpy movement over a final bulge gets you to ledge and anchors.

 Stick clip optional here. Basically an off-the-ground V2 boulder problem to easier face climbing gets you to the second bolt.
content.location: Left end of Live Wall face.

content.description: Climb Lower Rosie and then head left to the headwall between the chimney and splitter crack.
content.protection: 12 bolts, 2 fixed clips, to fixed anchor.
content.location: Start up Renaissance/ Lower Rosie

content.description: Climb bullet solid but low angle rock past several bolts to anchors below the overhanging arête
content.location: Right side of Renaissance Wall at the edge of the brush. The furthest right line on the wall

content.description:
High first and second bolt but only 4th class climbing to reach them.   

  Traverse right at second bolt to wide crack then eventually back onto face to below roof.  At crux bulge, reach far left under roof to a good hold and some powerful movement up to bolted crack section. 15-foot runout at top on 5.7 ground to reach anchors.   

* At the crux-reach-left, dont clip the bolt in the roof bulge (that is for the direct variation "Legends...") unless you have a long sling.  It will be tempting but will shut you down if you only use a quickdraw on it. If you do, you might as well finish on "Legends...".  Most people will, I suspect. ***Shorter-reach people will have trouble with the long crux move left but can use an even more powerful gaston intermediate to help with the reach. Im 6' tall with a slight negative AI and had to use the gaston move.
content.location: First route you come to, north end of Shack.

content.description:
Technical start up to dihedral corner, then technical transition to face, then pumpy steep climbing to ledge anchors. 

  Great Route!!!  Will challenge all your skills.
content.location: Center of Live Wall.

content.description:
Trad-climbers will love this one. 

  This may become the more popular variation of LRP, as shorter reachers may opt for the direct line through the roof. 

  Climb 4th-class to second bolt, traverse right into OW, then back onto face and up through deceivingly tricky bulge (pulling bulge not the hard move, save your celebrations) to large ledge.  

  At the second bulge crux from the ledge clip a high bolt then you can choose to pass it via the obvious and classic overhang-undercling or stay low and traverse left below the bolt on face holds.  fortunately, you can take your time from the ledge figuring this one out, there is no right answer.
content.location: Same start as for "Look Reach Pull" but head straight over the first roof bulge (5th bolt) to enter a completely different and challenging 40 foot crux section before rejoining the original line again at the top.

content.description: Starts with interesting movement on moderate ground through 5 bolts until the terrain gets steeper.  Once under the roof, you can easily reach back and clip the first crux bolt behind you and then launch out left to pull the power roof.
content.location: left side of the crag, just left of Endurance corner.

content.description: Climb a steep technical face past five bolts then move left onto steep juggy terrain.  Puzzle and power through steep dihedrals to the finish.
content.location: The route is located on the wall just right of Urban Legend.  The start is just left of "Thousand Yards of Drift"

content.description: Start on arete right of Renegade Wall and do tricky low-angle face moves to anchor.
content.location: Arete on left end of Live Wall.

content.description:
Face climb up to a roof block, pull around the block to the base of a headwall.  Rest up here before you pass the headwall to easier slab above.  Bolted anchors.  

  Quite a fun route with enjoyable movement.
content.location: Just right of Legends of the Fall.

content.description: Climb past the slab on "Tupper-Where" into a dihedral up and left. Then climb out right onto the face to a techy 2-bolt boulder problem with shit feet and flat crimps.
content.protection: False Hope is bolted, with anchors.
content.location: Extension of "Tupper-Where"

content.description: Basicaly follows a crack with a low roof and section of delicate face climbing.  Some rotten rock, but super fun otherwise. (60m rope does NOT reach)
content.location: Right of Fire on the Mountain

content.description: Center of Renegade Wall   Climb face moves to a crimpy-steep bulge.
content.location: just right of 40-Love

content.description:
First route on the Renaissance Wall, just south of Live Wall.  Start under steep block near arete.  climb through decent movement up to a ledge with bolted anchor.   

  Good for warming up and getting accustomed to Diablo-Style movement. 

  Might be some loose rock at the top-out.  With some traffic this should clean up OK.
content.location: Just right of Live Wall, on Renaissance Wall.  Start under steep block near arete.

content.description: Fun climbing on good rock. A great addition to the 5.10 circuit at this crag.
content.protection: 7 bolts to a shared anchor with Frogger
content.location: Between Pull to Live and Frogger. This is the lower half of Centipede (5.12a.) Climbs to the Frogger anchor.

content.description: Extension to Centipede-Lower. Head to first anchors, then ascend the steep headwall above to upper anchors. Optional to clip right-most anchor bolt, It will help to keep the rope out of your feet while moving into steeper headwall.
content.location: Between Pull to Live and Frogger.

content.description:
This line climbs like a 4-star route, the movement is superb!  The hanging block will make people think twice before heading up it and that is why I only gave it 3 stars.  Several people pried, hammered, and pulled on this block and couldn't even get it to creak.  No sign of any movement so we decided to just climb over it.   

  The route starts up a bulge on an arete and moves left onto the face through some great features, up towards a scary looking hanging block. Traverse left on blocks and ledges up to a rest, clip a fixed draw, and pull the upper bulge/roof to an easier dihedral finish.
content.location: right of 1000 yards of drift, just left of City Girl.

content.description:
With the 2nd pitch, City Girl becomes Big City Girl.  It can be done as 1 long pitch, but be aware of rope drag (consider backcleaning or using long runners in some places). 

  Start with the 5.9 City Girl arête to its anchor. Traverse left to a bolt and pull crux moves along the crumbly arête. Continue up 5.9 terrain passing 2 more bulges. At the last roof, turn it directly, or slightly to the right, or you'll miss the last bolt. 

  A 60m rope reaches, up and down, with very little to spare.
content.protection: 17? bolts total, according to my list (but I think it wasn't quite that many)
content.location: This is the full version of City Girl.

climbs.name: A Thousand Yards of Drift (the whole route)

content.description:
Start on "A Thousand Yards of Drift", then clip the bolt on the roof and pull a hard boulder problem onto the face of a pillar above.  Sustained climbing above on the pillar. 

  Aesthetic position.
content.location: Starts on an arete just right of "Live to Pull". First bolt could be stick clipped, but people 5'10" should be able to reach the first bolt easy enough from a stance.

content.description: Fantastic and technical climbing. Start through hard face climbing to a steep and pumpy section and a technical pull over the lip. Then a few more face moves to the anchor. I established this route on a particular rainy solo outing on my 40th birthday. It was a great blessing to my otherwise dreary turning of decade.
content.location: Just right of "We Were Jumpers..." on the Renegade Wall.

climbs.name: A Thousand Yards of Drift  (just the start)

content.description: A good warmup on an arete. some tricky footwork through the short steep section.
content.location: On the Live Wall, the arete to the right of Live to Pull that heads up to roof system above.  There is an anchor just under the roof and then a bolt line that leads into the "Hookup" from here.

content.description: Start up the arete, reach left and clip the first bolt, then make techy moves left onto a good ledge and continue up through lots of fun movement and a steep bulge above.
content.location: The small panel of rock that transitions between the Renegade sector and the Live sector

content.description: The primary area of the Standby Shack. This is the obvious, large west-facing wall with the bulk of the routes at the crag.
